Hello and welcome everyone. I'm Corey Hofstein and this is Flirting with Models, the podcast that pulls back the curtain to discover the human factor behind the quantitative strategy. Corey Hofstein is the co-founder and chief investment officer of Newfound Research. Due to industry regulations, he will not discuss any of Newfound Research's funds on this podcast. All opinions expressed by podcast participants are solely their own opinion and do not reflect the opinion of Newfound Research. This podcast is for informational purposes only and should not be relied upon as a basis for investment decisions. Clients of Newfound Research may maintain positions and securities discussed in this podcast. For more information, visit thinknewfound.com. In this episode, I chat with Toby Carlisle, a managing member at Carbon Beach Asset Management and author of popular value investing books such as Deep Value and The Acquirer's Multiple. Toby's approach to value investing evolved from his observations as a corporate lawyer in Australia during the burst of the dot-com bubble. Watching investors target cash-rich but business-poor dot-com companies confused his traditional discounted cash flow mentality. But after watching these activists get their hands dirty, Toby realized that even bad companies can be attractive if they're trading at a deep discount to liquidation value. In our conversation, we navigate a wide range of topics, including uses and limits of quantitative investing in the realm of special situations, how under the right circumstances even Apple can be a deep value stock, and why using the opposite of your investment signal to build a short book might be a bad idea. Without further ado, please enjoy my conversation with Toby Carlisle. Toby, thank you for joining me today. Thanks for having me, Corey. So let's start at the beginning for you, man. Clearly, not born and raised in America with that Australian accent. Why don't you give us a story of how you came to live states?

大家好，欢迎收听。我是Corey Hofstein，这里是《Flirting with Models》，这个播客揭开了量化策略背后的人性因素。Corey Hofstein是Newfound Research的联合创始人和首席投资官。由于行业规定，他不会在这个播客中讨论任何Newfound Research的基金。播客参与者的所有观点仅代表他们自己的意见，并不反映Newfound Research的意见。本播客仅用于信息目的，不应作为投资决策的依据。Newfound Research的客户可能持有本播客中讨论的仓位和证券。更多信息，请访问thinknewfound.com。在本期节目中，我与Toby Carlisle进行了对话，他是Carbon Beach Asset Management的管理成员，也是《Deep Value》和《The Acquirer's Multiple》等畅销价值投资书籍的作者。Toby的价值投资方法源于他在澳大利亚担任企业律师期间，目睹了互联网泡沫的破裂。看到投资者瞄准现金流充裕但业务贫乏的互联网公司，这让他的传统折现现金流思维感到困惑。但在观察这些激进投资者的实际行动后，Toby意识到，即使是不好的公司，如果它们以远低于清算价值的价格交易，也可能具有吸引力。在我们的对话中，我们探讨了广泛的主题，包括量化投资在特殊情况下的应用和局限性，在适当的情况下，即使是苹果公司也可以成为深度价值股票，以及为什么使用与你的投资信号相反的方法来构建空头组合可能是一个坏主意。事不宜迟，请享受我与Toby Carlisle的对话。Toby，感谢你今天加入我。谢谢你邀请我，Corey。那么，让我们从你的故事开始吧。显然，你不是在美国出生和长大的，从你的澳大利亚口音就能听出来。为什么不给我们讲讲你是如何来到美国的呢？

Interviewer
side. I'm born and raised in Australia. Grew up in a little country town way in the outback. One of my subjects at school was how to shear sheep. This is a real thing. They talk about ring banging the bush mob. That means cutting some of the hair on the tail so you can distinguish the cows in this instance, the cattle that have been treated, knocking the horns off, branding them. Went to university and I did business and then law school. Went to work in a law firm in Australia doing mergers and acquisitions. My first day of work was April 2000. The dot-com had peaked or was literally just about to peak. I thought I had been brought in to do IPOs of tech companies because that was what everybody was doing at that stage. I thought that was really interesting. They just disappeared. There was no means of raising money anymore. There were lots of mergers and acquisitions though because that was the turn of the market. Companies are still buying other companies. It was just a very interesting time. I think that's what I've been doing. I've been doing a lot of happy coincidence that it was at this time. There were these new investors who were doing interesting things. One of the things they were doing was targeting these companies that were dot-coms that raised a whole lot of money but had this cash burn. They were literally selling $10 widgets for $20 and losing $10 in every sale and trying to make it up on volume. I had read in college Buffett's letters and I'd forced myself to sit down and read the 1934 edition of security analysis, which is really, really dry. It's mostly about railway bonds, which I don't think there are any publicly traded railways in Australia at the time. I'd be hard-pressed to find very many in the States too. These guys were targeting these busted companies that were terrible businesses. I was trying to apply my Buffett return on invested capital. Buffett prefers these wonderful businesses at fair prices. They're trying to apply that to these businesses. You just can't do a DCF on something that's losing money. You end up with this negative value. These guys were buying these things, couldn't quite figure out what they were doing. Eventually, I realized this is one of those examples of a little bit of understanding about something actually makes it really hard to understand what's actually going on. The Buffett stuff did not help. Basically, these guys wanted the cash on the balance sheet. That raised a whole lot of money. They're trading a big discount to that cash. There's no reason why these things are ordained to lose money forever and ever. If you get in and stop that silly business, then you've got valuable assets. You've got to be able to get in and stop that silly business. You bought it at a big discount. Then you can keep on doing that. We didn't know what they were called at the time. I subsequently become activists, but there was no name for them at the time. I collected a lot of information, became very interested in it, became a little part of the practice. Mostly, it was defense because we were working for bigger clients. These guys were mostly young guys who had little hedge funds who were being obnoxious to try and draw attention to the fact that these things were so cheap. I went back to the security analysis later chapters in two of these chapters back to back. One talks about buying at the discount to liquidation value, and the other one talks about shareholder rights. That was what started me down the path towards deep value investment.

我在澳大利亚出生和长大，成长在一个偏远的小镇。在学校里，我学过如何剪羊毛，这可是真事儿。他们还教我们如何“环割”牛群，这意味着剪掉一些尾巴上的毛，以便区分那些已经处理过的牛，比如去角、打烙印等。后来我上了大学，学习了商科和法律。毕业后，我在澳大利亚的一家律师事务所工作，主要负责并购业务。我的第一天工作是在2000年4月，那时互联网泡沫刚刚达到顶峰或即将达到顶峰。我以为我会参与科技公司的IPO，因为那时每个人都在做这个。但突然间，这些机会消失了，融资渠道也关闭了。不过，并购业务依然很多，因为市场正在转变，公司仍在收购其他公司。那是一个非常有趣的时期。我认为我一直在做的事情，很多都是在这个时期偶然发生的。 那时有一些新的投资者在做有趣的事情。他们瞄准了那些虽然筹集了大量资金但现金流紧张的互联网公司。这些公司实际上是在以亏损的价格销售产品，试图通过销量来弥补损失。我在大学时读过巴菲特的信件，还强迫自己读了1934年版的《证券分析》，那本书非常枯燥，主要讲的是铁路债券，而当时澳大利亚几乎没有公开交易的铁路公司。这些投资者瞄准了那些经营不善的公司。我试图应用巴菲特的投资回报率理论，但巴菲特更喜欢那些价格合理的优秀企业。他们试图将这一理论应用到这些公司上，但你无法对一个亏损的企业进行现金流折现分析，最终你会得到一个负值。这些人购买了这些公司的股票，但不太清楚他们在做什么。最终，我意识到，对某些事情的一点点了解反而会让你更难理解实际情况。巴菲特的理论并没有帮助。 基本上，这些人想要的是公司资产负债表上的现金。这些公司筹集了大量资金，他们的股票以大幅折价交易。没有理由认为这些公司会永远亏损。如果你介入并停止那些愚蠢的业务，那么你就拥有了有价值的资产。你必须能够介入并停止那些愚蠢的业务，你以大幅折价购买了这些资产，然后你可以继续这样做。那时我们不知道这些策略叫什么，后来我成为了激进投资者，但当时并没有这个名称。我收集了很多信息，对此非常感兴趣，并逐渐参与其中。大多数时候，我们是在为更大的客户做防御性工作。这些人大多是年轻的对冲基金经理，他们通过挑衅来吸引人们对这些廉价股票的关注。 后来，我重新阅读了《证券分析》的后几章，其中两章连续讨论了以低于清算价值的价格购买股票和股东权利。这让我走上了深度价值投资的道路。

So you get introduced to this style of investing through the law firm. When did you first get your hands dirty actually doing the investing yourself?

所以你是通过律师事务所接触到这种投资风格的。你是什么时候开始亲自动手进行投资的呢？

Interviewer
It took a long time. You have some difficulty investing when you're a lawyer for big companies that are publicly listed because at any moment, one of them could catch a bid. And it's not a good look if the junior lawyer has a long position in it that he bought a few weeks ago. So we were prevented from investing in just about anything. The first time I really got an opportunity was when I got transferred to the U.S. office. And I thought now it's safe to invest back in Australia. And it's pretty much it was safe in the States as well just because the nature of the work that I was doing was if a multinational had multi, multi-billion dollar acquisition, but they had lots of subs through Southeast Asia or Australia or the Asia Pacific, we had lots of offices. So we could sort of implement that part of the transaction for them. But it was very unlikely that I was ever going to get caught. So it was into the 2000s, 2005, something like that, that I had a little bit of investment capital. And the first thing I ever bought was Budweiser. Because Warren Buffett bought Budweiser, that was the extent of my analysis. And it went up and it got taken over eventually. So it worked out OK. But I didn't do anything other than follow Buffett into the stock. I remembered vividly what had happened in the early 2000s, that these really busted little businesses had got very, very cheap. And I thought if that ever happens again, if we ever get another stock market crash, basically the same thought process that I have now, if we ever see another stock market crash, as impossible as that appears to be in every single market, I'm going to have to get back in the stock market. Because if that happened again, if things got cheap enough, then I would go and dig up all of these net cash, net net, sub liquidation value companies with the additional requirement that they would have an activist who had already filed a 13D in the States. And I would buy them and rely on the fact that the activists would work or the market would sort of figure it out. So when 2007 came around, I geared up to do that. And I bought a whole lot of stocks. And I started writing this little blog called Greenbacked, which basically just did exactly that. Looked for net nets. Whether it was in a stock market or not. activist.

这需要很长时间。当你是大公司（尤其是上市公司）的律师时，投资会有一些困难，因为任何时候，其中一家公司都可能被收购。如果初级律师几周前就持有了这家公司的多头头寸，那看起来就不太好了。所以我们几乎被禁止投资任何东西。我真正有机会投资是在我被调到美国办公室的时候。那时我觉得可以安全地投资回澳大利亚了。在美国也差不多是安全的，因为我的工作性质是，如果一家跨国公司有数十亿美元的大型收购，而这些收购涉及东南亚、澳大利亚或亚太地区的许多子公司，我们有很多办公室，可以为他们处理这部分交易。但被牵连的可能性非常小。所以到了2000年代，大约2005年左右，我有了一些投资资本。我买的第一只股票是百威啤酒，因为沃伦·巴菲特买了它，这就是我的全部分析。它涨了，最终被收购了。结果还不错。但我除了跟随巴菲特买入股票外，没有做其他事情。我清晰地记得2000年代初发生的事情，那些真正陷入困境的小企业变得非常便宜。我想，如果这种情况再次发生，如果我们再次遭遇股市崩盘，基本上和我现在的想法一样，如果再看到一次股市崩盘，尽管这在每个市场看起来都不可能，我将不得不重新进入股市。因为如果这种情况再次发生，如果价格足够便宜，我会去找那些净现金、净清算价值的公司，并且它们在美国已经有激进投资者提交了13D文件。我会买入它们，并依靠激进投资者的工作或市场自行解决。所以到了2007年，我准备这样做。我买了很多股票，并开始写一个叫Greenbacked的小博客，基本上就是做这件事：寻找净净公司，无论它们是否在股市中，是否有激进投资者。

没错，正是如此。对于不了解的人来说，澳大利亚市场有一半是金融股，另外大约三分之一到六分之一是基础材料股，也就是矿业，这符合预期。加拿大市场也非常相似。我认为信息技术股只占大约半个百分点。而如果你看MSCI指数，信息技术股大约占12%到13%。我认为美国可能还要更高一些。所以，这些领域是低配的。然而，在互联网泡沫时期，人们却热衷于此。如果你能想出一个域名，并且对某个行业有模糊的占领想法，你几乎可以随便推出一个项目。澳大利亚市场有点像加拿大，可能更容易——人们对矿业，尤其是投机性矿业、初级矿业有兴趣。他们除了打算在某处钻探的意图外，没有任何资产。他们也不知道是否能找到什么。这有点像美国的生物科技股。在美国也有一些类似的投机性公司。但基本上——基本上，这些公司没有商业模式。他们的想法是，如果我们找到了什么，那么我们都会赚大钱。但大多数时候，他们什么也没找到。

Interviewer
Just that all of a sudden there were these net nets and sub-liquidation players that hadn't really been available in number were all of a sudden available. It had gone from being something like fewer than 100 to maybe 350, something like that. So there were enough that being selective, I could pick out the ones that had an activist. 突然之间，这些净净资产和接近清算的参与者数量大幅增加，之前数量并不多，现在突然变得可用。从之前的不到100家，增加到可能的350家左右。因此，有足够多的选择，我可以挑选出那些有活跃投资者的公司。它们拥有净现金，相对于净净资产有非常大的折扣。我认为这些资产很可能被低估了。而且，如果世界末日来临，我持有的资产至少还有清算价值。

Customer
Now we're going to end up ultimately talking about your whole series of books because Greenbacked was your first. You ultimately wrote Quantitative Value with our friend Wes Gray. You wrote Deep Value. Most recently you wrote Acquirer's Multiple. And I know there has been an evolution of your investment process. In writing the Greenbacked blog, was this an approach that you were trying to systematize or was this sort of a special situations type opportunity?

现在我们最终要讨论的是你整个系列的书籍，因为《Greenbacked》是你的第一本。你最终与我们的朋友Wes Gray合著了《Quantitative Value》，写了《Deep Value》，最近又写了《Acquirer's Multiple》。我知道你的投资过程有一个演变。在撰写《Greenbacked》博客时，你是在尝试系统化这种方法，还是这是一种特殊情况类型的机会？

Interviewer
It was more special situations and I was going through, you can do net net style investing quantitatively. That's entirely possible to do it that way. And I had gone through and sort of cherry picked out the ones that had an activist. I felt good about the assets that they had. There was more cash than sort of inventory, which might be hard to sell. Maybe the inventory should be written down by this amount because it's not worth anything anymore. I got to the end of 2009 after the market had recovered. And I looked at the returns of the ones that I had picked out and they did really well. It was like 250% over that year in the course of these ones that I had identified and cherry picked out. And I thought, I'm really good at this stuff. And then I thought just to torture myself, I'll go and look at what the entire cohort of whatever it was, 250 or 350 stocks that I bought 30 say out of that group. So pretty selective, less than a decile. What did the whole cohort? The cohort did 750%. So how did I mess that up so badly? That was the thought that I had. Basically, you get a handful of stocks that go up 20, 50 times. And if you don't catch those ones that perform like that, you underperform. And that's basically quant investing. You need a bigger portfolio because you're going to get this right tail of returns and you need to capture those returns.

这是一种特殊情况，我正在经历，你可以通过量化方式进行净净风格的投资。完全有可能以这种方式进行。我经历了一遍，并挑选出了那些有激进投资者的公司。我对他们拥有的资产感到满意。现金比库存多，库存可能很难出售。也许库存应该按这个数额减记，因为它已经没有任何价值了。2009年底，市场恢复后，我查看了我挑选的那些公司的回报，它们表现得非常好。那一年它们的回报率达到了250%，这些是我识别并精心挑选出来的。我心想，我在这方面真的很擅长。然后我又想，为了折磨自己，我会去看看整个群体的表现，不管它是250还是350只股票，我买了其中的30只。所以非常精选，不到十分之一。整个群体的表现如何？群体的表现是750%。所以我怎么会搞砸得这么严重？这就是我当时所想的。基本上，你会得到一些上涨20倍、50倍的股票。如果你没有抓住那些表现如此出色的股票，你就会表现不佳。这基本上就是量化投资。你需要一个更大的投资组合，因为你需要抓住那些高回报的股票。

Yeah, that was the beginning of the journey. I read James Montier, great value investor and value kind of philosopher, had written this great piece called An Ode to Quant. And I read that and I saw in there that he said that there was this phenomenon in social studies, which is pretty pronounced. Basically, the idea is that simple statistical models, simple algorithms outperform the intuition of the best experts, which sounds nuts. But it's common. You find this over and over again in the literature. And I think in 1975, Paul Meal, who's regarded as the godfather of this area of studies, said something like, when you see these studies over and over again reporting the same result, at some stage, you have to sort of acknowledge that this is a phenomenon, that our behavior in these things is sort of deleterious to our expertise. And it's not just in investing, it's in selecting wine vintages, determining which criminal... Is it going to be recidivists, college admissions? It's over and over again, all of these different areas where we just, we fool ourselves. So the classic example is a story where a Professor Goldberg, who was a, I think he was a psychologist, and he was looking at when people present in a hospital, if your schizophrenia and very deep depression can manifest the same way, there's a little bit of psychosis in the deep depression. And it can be very difficult to determine whether somebody who's having some sort of, you know, ideation that is a little not connected to reality, and someone who's schizophrenic is not connected to reality. So he came up with this six question framework, and he asked people these questions. And then subsequently, when they were treated, down the track, two weeks or a month later, they were able to make a diagnosis, a proper diagnosis. And then they could go back and look at the way that they presented initially and determine, was our initial diagnosis correct or not? And they had students ask these six questions and make a diagnosis based on the six questions. Then they gave it to treating clinicians, and they had them do the same thing, but they didn't have to follow the recommendation. So they found that basically the clinicians who applied this rule got better results than people who didn't apply this sort of questionnaire. But they found that the questionnaire by itself, which was applied by the students without fear or favour, outperformed the best clinicians, even with the benefit of the questionnaire. So somebody with years and years of experience, presumably, doing this stuff all the time, with the benefit of the questionnaire, which is guiding them in the right direction, still doesn't do as well as this dumb six question questionnaire. And that's something that you see over and over again as a quant. The reason why this happens is this idea, the broken leg theory. So the broken leg theory is best explained in the story, the way it's described in literature. You have this quant model that determines whether an individual goes to theatre on a Friday night. And you might include. And that quant model thinks like, is it raining outside that might stop them from going? Is it an action movie which this person prefers or is it a romance movie which they don't want to see? So you have your six factors in your quant model. And then you learn on one Friday that the person has a broken leg. And do you therefore override the model to allow for the fact that a broken leg might mean you're less likely to go to the theatre? Or do you then follow the model which doesn't have that information in it? And the answer is that you have to keep on following the model. And the. Reason is that we exercise our discretion far too frequently. We find lots of reasons to override the model, too many reasons to override the model. And that's particularly true when you do what I do, which is buy deep value stocks. Every single one of these stocks has a broken leg.

是的，那是我旅程的开始。我读了詹姆斯·蒙蒂尔的作品，他是一位伟大的价值投资者和价值哲学家，写了一篇名为《量化颂》的精彩文章。我读了那篇文章，发现他在其中提到社会研究中存在一种显著的现象。基本上，这个观点是说简单的统计模型和算法能够超越最优秀专家的直觉，这听起来很疯狂，但却是常见的。你在文献中一遍又一遍地看到这种现象。我认为在1975年，保罗·梅尔，被认为是这个研究领域的鼻祖，曾说过类似的话，当你一遍又一遍地看到这些研究报告相同的结果时，在某个阶段，你必须承认这是一个现象，我们在这些事情上的行为对我们的专业知识是有害的。这不仅仅是在投资领域，在选择葡萄酒年份、判断罪犯是否会再次犯罪、大学录取等方面也是如此。我们在这些不同的领域中一遍又一遍地欺骗自己。所以经典的例子是一个关于戈德伯格教授的故事，我想他是一位心理学家，他研究的是当人们在医院就诊时，如果一个人同时患有精神分裂症和深度抑郁症，这两种情况可能会以相同的方式表现出来，深度抑郁症中可能会有一点精神病症状。这使得很难区分一个有轻微脱离现实想法的人和一个精神分裂症患者。因此，他设计了一个包含六个问题的框架，并询问人们这些问题。随后，当他们接受治疗时，两周或一个月后，他们能够做出正确的诊断。然后他们可以回顾最初的诊断，确定最初的诊断是否正确。他们让学生根据这六个问题做出诊断，然后将结果交给治疗临床医生，临床医生也做了同样的事情，但他们不必遵循建议。结果发现，应用这个规则的临床医生比没有应用这种问卷的人取得了更好的结果。但他们发现，这个问卷本身，由学生无偏见地应用，表现优于最好的临床医生，即使他们有问卷的帮助。所以，即使是有多年经验的人，在问卷的正确指导下，仍然不如这个简单的六个问题的问卷表现得好。作为一名量化分析师，你会一遍又一遍地看到这种现象。这种现象发生的原因是“断腿理论”。断腿理论在文献中是这样解释的：你有一个量化模型，决定一个人是否会在周五晚上去剧院。你可能包括的因素有：外面是否在下雨，这可能会阻止他们去？这是一部这个人喜欢的动作片，还是他们不想看的爱情片？所以你的量化模型中有六个因素。然后你在某个周五得知这个人腿断了。你会因此推翻模型，考虑到断腿可能意味着他们不太可能去剧院吗？还是你会继续遵循没有这个信息的模型？答案是你必须继续遵循模型。原因是我们在太多情况下行使了我们的判断。我们找到了太多推翻模型的理由，尤其是在我从事的领域——购买深度价值股票时，每只股票都有“断腿”。

tell us. I keep on telling that story. I'm happy to hear from whoever coined it. The reason that I describe it the way that I do and the way that I found it, Buffett talks about operating income. He regularly talks about operating EBIT operating income as the way that Buffett describes it. So it's an apples to apples comparison of correcting for the capital structure, looking at interest and taxes and adding those things back in. So you're looking at basically the accounting definition of cash flows that's coming into the business. And then on the other hand, you're looking at enterprise value, which is market capitalization, lets you know what the equity is worth. Enterprise value includes other things that an acquirer of the business really has to pay. And that's, they have to find a way to service the debt or pay out the debt. If there are any preference shares in there, they have to find a way to service them or pay them off, minority interests, other things like that. So these are real costs an acquirer of the business has to pay. So those two metrics together give you a good idea of what the residue of the business that you're actually paying for is. And then what you're getting in return in terms of operating income. Buffett has been a long term value investor whose value investment has sort of evolved over time from, he was probably a deep value investor in the more of Graham. And by virtue of meeting Charlie Munger and reading Phil Fisher, he became a more sort of growth quality franchise, high return on invested capital type investor. So Joel Greenblatt wrote a wonderful book that came out in 2006 called The Little Book That Beats the Market. And in there, he advocates for this metric that he calls the magic formula. On one hand, it uses the acquirer's multiple EBIT operating income on enterprise value. And on the other hand, it uses return on invested capital. And the idea of return on invested capital is you're looking for how much profit does this company generate for how much money is invested in it. And the more profitable it is per dollar invested in it, the better the business is, which makes perfect sense because that kind of business can compound at a very high rate. And so that's what we're looking for. And then you've got to look at the return on invested capital rate. It can become very, very profitable with sort of marginal investment in it. And when you combine that with a value factor, you're getting these very high quality, high compounding kind of businesses at a cheap price. So Greenblatt tested in the book over 12 years or something like that, and it worked well. We tested it again. So quantitative value, which came out in 2012, Wes Gray and I tested that and found that that does in fact beat the market, even doing stuff like it's not a small company effect. Limit yourself to the biggest companies in the market. If you then market capitalization weight those companies, you still outperform the market capitalization weighted index. So it's a very, very good metric. In the course of doing that, I thought, how is it that return on invested capital metric stands up so well? Because my own personal experience of buying these companies is that you're buying companies at the very pinnacle of their business cycle and you see mean reversion in the profitability. So you buy something that looks really cheap, you acquire as multiple metric and it looks really good, but the mean reverse is that you buy something that looks really cheap and reversion in the return on invested capital and the profitability, they become less cheap and less good in the period after you own them. And so I thought, what if we just tested this without looking at the profitability metric? What does that do? Just randomize that error rather than focus on that error. And it turns out you do better in a raw performance sense and in a risk adjusted sense, which is the most surprising thing. So the reasons are mostly it's that return on invested capital identifies these companies right at the pinnacle of their business cycle. So you're encouraging competitors from adjacent industries to come in and compete away for those dollars, which just makes sense. There aren't very many free lunches in the market. And on the other hand, the very worst companies, you can think about many industries that have beaten up people in the industry leave because it's so hard to make money or they do it forcibly because they just bankrupted. And it creates this period where there's not very much capital in the industry. There's not very many businesses there. So when the oil price, say, comes back, if you want to access that, you've got to do it. And that's why I think it's so important to go through these oil field services companies that are left, the ones that were able to survive, and they have a period of super normal profitability. And I think that's the reason why not looking at the return on investment, just randomizing that error tends to do better than focusing on ROIC.

告诉我们吧。我一直在讲那个故事。我很高兴听到谁是这个概念的创造者。我之所以这样描述它，以及我找到它的方式，是因为巴菲特谈论的是营业利润。他经常谈论营业EBIT，即巴菲特所描述的营业利润。因此，这是一个苹果对苹果的比较，修正了资本结构，考虑了利息和税收，并将这些因素加回去。所以你基本上是在看企业流入的现金流量的会计定义。另一方面，你在看企业价值，即市值，它告诉你股权的价值。企业价值还包括收购者真正需要支付的其他东西。他们必须找到一种方式来偿还债务或支付债务。如果有任何优先股，他们必须找到一种方式来偿还或支付它们，还有少数股东权益等其他事项。所以这些都是收购者必须支付的实际成本。这两个指标一起，可以很好地了解你实际支付的企业剩余价值是什么，以及你在营业利润方面得到了什么回报。巴菲特一直是一个长期的价值投资者，他的价值投资随着时间的推移而演变，从他可能是格雷厄姆式的深度价值投资者，到通过与查理·芒格的会面和阅读菲尔·费舍尔的书籍，他成为了一个更注重增长、质量和投资资本高回报的投资者。所以乔尔·格林布拉特写了一本很棒的书，2006年出版的《打败市场的小书》。在书中，他提倡他称之为“神奇公式”的指标。一方面，它使用了收购者倍数EBIT营业利润与企业价值。另一方面，它使用了投资资本回报率。投资资本回报率的概念是，你在寻找这家公司为投入的资金产生了多少利润。每投入一美元，它产生的利润越多，这个企业就越好，这完全合理，因为这样的企业可以以非常高的速度复合增长。这就是我们在寻找的。然后你必须看投资资本回报率。它可以变得非常非常盈利，只需要边际投资。当你将这一点与价值因素结合起来时，你就能以便宜的价格获得这些高质量、高复合增长的企业。所以格林布拉特在书中测试了12年左右，效果很好。我们再次测试了它。所以《量化价值》，2012年出版的，韦斯·格雷和我测试了它，发现它确实能打败市场，即使是在做一些事情，比如它不是小公司效应。限制自己在市场上最大的公司。如果你然后按市值加权这些公司，你仍然能跑赢市值加权指数。所以这是一个非常好的指标。在研究过程中，我想，投资资本回报率指标为什么表现得这么好？因为根据我自己的个人经验，购买这些公司时，你是在它们业务周期的顶峰买入的，你会看到盈利能力的均值回归。所以你买的东西看起来真的很便宜，你使用的倍数指标看起来真的很好，但均值回归意味着你买的东西看起来真的很便宜，投资资本回报率和盈利能力的回归，它们在你拥有它们之后变得不那么便宜和好了。所以我就在想，如果我们不考虑盈利能力指标，只测试这个会怎么样？只是随机化那个错误，而不是专注于那个错误。结果发现，你在原始表现和风险调整意义上都表现得更好，这是最令人惊讶的事情。所以原因主要是投资资本回报率识别出这些公司正好处于它们业务周期的顶峰。所以你鼓励邻近行业的竞争对手进来争夺那些美元，这完全合理。市场上没有很多免费的午餐。另一方面，最糟糕的公司，你可以想到很多行业，人们因为太难赚钱而离开，或者他们被迫离开，因为他们破产了。这创造了一个时期，行业中没有很多资本，也没有很多企业。所以当油价回升时，如果你想进入，你必须这么做。这就是为什么我认为通过这些幸存的油田服务公司非常重要，它们能够生存下来，并且有一个超常盈利的时期。我认为这就是为什么不去看投资回报率，只是随机化那个错误，往往比专注于ROIC表现得更好。

If you look for the good ways of doing it, I think Michael Malbison has, the best sort of analysis of it. He's been running this experiment on an ongoing basis. Basically, he looks at a cohort of companies and then he tracks their return on invested capital forward over 10 years. And so he divides them into, take every company in the universe, the top 1,000 businesses, divide them into five groups. The first group has the very highest return on invested capital. The fifth group has the very lowest return on invested capital. And inevitably, they follow the same performance. The whole group is the same. The highest return on invested capital trends down towards the average. The lowest return on invested capital trends up towards the average. When you look at that as a group, what he's saying is basically return on invested capital is highly mean reverting. So how do you find the ones that resist that? About 4% of companies are able to sort of resist this and they have this every year. They turn out a pretty good return on invested capital that is better than the average. They're able to sustain that compound year after year after year. And the companies that aren't particularly glamorous, they're often companies that have, you know, so for a long time, P&G, they have these branded consumer goods that sit on supermarket shelves. Band-Aid, lots of things like that. Johnson & Johnson has lots of these little products that it doesn't cost them very much to make. They're able to sell them at a high margin. Everybody goes in. You're not going to buy a knockoff version of Band-Aid. You want the Band-Aid brand of Band-Aids. And so they're able to earn a pretty good return. And on the other side, it's also true. In the cohort that is the worst, that trends back to average, there is a group in there that are just set up to fail. You never want to buy the very worst return on invested capital. So they're the dot-coms that don't have a business model. They're the miners or the junior miners that don't have a deposit. They're sort of, they're using shareholder money to hunt for that deposit. If they strike it rich, they do well. But as a cohort, they don't do well. So they lose money on average. So return on invested capital on average is not a good metric. But the very worst are. Stocks that you want to avoid. Malverson has sort of looked at the ones that that 4% that are able to avoid the mean reversion. He's looked at that. He's devolved their returns using the DuPont analysis. Is it a high margin with a low turnover? Or is it a thin margin with a high turnover? It tends to be a higher margin with a lower turnover. Tends to be a better business. But he's not able to prospectively identify with each new cohort, which will be the ones that will resist mean reversion in the next 10 years.

在我完成那项研究后，我重新回顾并阅读了所有的信件。我已经多次这样做，反复阅读他的所有信件。每次阅读，我都能发现一些新的东西，如果我没有这样做，我就学到了一些东西，然后我会回去再读一遍，发现巴菲特在50年前就已经知道这些，并且一直在试图解释，只是我第一次阅读时没有理解。当你阅读他的信件时，他真正在说的是这些是护城河的经济学。我们不是在寻找仅仅是投资资本回报率。那几乎可以说是我们在寻找的东西的症状，我们在寻找的是拥有护城河的公司。他一遍又一遍地这样说，而我是一个非常慢的学习者，所以我并没有真正理解。但他给出了所有他谈论的信件。这些都是护城河的标志。所以他有一种识别它们的方法。如果你试图接近，比如说你不具备巴菲特的天才，你需要找到某种科学或量化的方法来做这件事。我一直在寻找一种聪明的方法来做这件事，因为这也是一种击败市场的方法。如果你寻找好的方法，我认为迈克尔·马尔比森有最好的分析。他一直在持续进行这个实验。基本上，他看一组公司，然后跟踪它们未来10年的投资资本回报率。他将它们分成五组，从整个宇宙中挑选出前1000家企业，第一组拥有非常高的投资资本回报率，第五组拥有非常低的投资资本回报率。不可避免地，它们遵循相同的表现。整个组都是一样的。最高投资资本回报率的趋势是下降到平均水平，最低投资资本回报率的趋势是上升到平均水平。当你作为一个组来看时，他基本上是在说投资资本回报率具有高度均值回归性。那么你如何找到那些抵抗这种趋势的公司呢？大约4%的公司能够抵抗这种趋势，并且每年都这样做。他们每年都能产生比平均水平更好的投资资本回报率。他们能够年复一年地维持这种复合增长。而那些不特别引人注目的公司，通常是那些拥有长期品牌消费品的公司，比如宝洁，他们拥有这些放在超市货架上的品牌消费品。邦迪，很多类似的东西。强生公司有很多这样的小产品，生产成本不高，但能够以高利润销售。每个人都会去买。你不会去买邦迪的仿制品，你想要的是邦迪品牌的创可贴。因此他们能够获得相当不错的回报。另一方面，这也是真的。在最差的群体中，那些趋势回归平均的公司中，有一部分注定会失败。你永远不想购买那些投资资本回报率最差的公司。所以他们是那些没有商业模式的互联网公司。他们是那些没有矿藏的矿工或初级矿工。他们基本上是在用股东的钱去寻找那个矿藏。如果他们找到了，他们会做得很好。但作为一个群体，他们表现不佳。所以他们在平均水平上亏损。因此，平均投资资本回报率不是一个好的指标。但最差的那些是你想要避免的股票。马尔比森已经看了那些能够避免均值回归的4%的公司。他看了那些公司。他使用杜邦分析法分解了他们的回报。是高利润低周转率，还是薄利润高周转率？通常是高利润低周转率。这往往是一个更好的业务。但他无法前瞻性地识别出每个新群体中，哪些将在未来10年内抵抗均值回归。

Interviewer
I think there are three broad camps of value investors. There are the guys who are doing special situations, who are looking for genuine arbitrages, so whether it's a risk arbitrage or they're looking for an undervalued security hard catalyst. I think that's a very valid way of investing and generates returns that are sort of uncorrelated to the market and they're always going to be very idiosyncratic. Their returns that can be good in one year, bad in another year, doesn't really matter what the market does. Then distinct from that is another group and they exist on a spectrum and one end of that spectrum is the Buffett franchise guys. So they will want to do a DCF. They're assuming a very high return on invested capital, rapid growth over an extended period of time so they have some sort of sustainable moat there. And I think that when they do an analysis, they do a DCF style analysis. I think they'll often find that the implied PE is quite high for those people. So they might buy something at 40 times earnings thinking that it's worth 60 times earnings. I know lots of guys who are like that in that kind of camp and I say that the ick, the gag factor, I'm buying the stuff that's very ugly when I'm buying it and I have to kind of ignore the recent track record or my own personal feelings about the business in order to buy them. What they have to ignore is the valuation. So they'll look at 40 times earnings sounds like an insane. That could be very depressed earnings in my world, but in their world that's compound. And that's a way to value the company. Like 40 times earnings is expensive, but they think that it's going to compound and that's going to eventually be proven to be a cheap multiple. And the examples that they give are often something like Walmart. You can go back to when Walmart IPO'd in 1975, something like that in the 70s. And you can look at what multiple would have given you just the market return since it IPO'd. And it's something like you could have paid up to a thousand times something like that off the Richter scale of what you would consider to be value. And it would have delivered just a market return, which is still a pretty good return over that period of time. So that's one end of the spectrum. The other end of the spectrum is where I am, which is the deep value stocks. So these are companies that the business is questionable. There's not much business there. I think it's better than the market is giving it credit for, but I acknowledge that there are problems with the business. You're looking at a little bit of balance sheet value. Definitely not going to look at compounding. All of these things need to do for my strategy to work is for them to survive the next period of time and then to find that period of time. 我认为价值投资者大致可以分为三类。第一类是专注于特殊情况的投资人，他们寻找真正的套利机会，无论是风险套利还是寻找被低估且有强劲催化剂的证券。我认为这是一种非常有效的投资方式，产生的回报与市场相关性较低，且具有很强的独特性。他们的回报可能在某一年很好，而在另一年则可能不佳，与市场表现无关。 与上述不同的另一类投资者存在于一个连续谱系中，其中一端是巴菲特式的投资者。他们会进行贴现现金流（DCF）分析，假设投资资本的高回报率和在较长时间内的快速增长，因此他们认为公司具有某种可持续的竞争优势。我认为他们在进行分析时，通常会采用DCF风格的分析。他们往往会发现，这些公司的隐含市盈率（PE）相当高。因此，他们可能会以40倍的市盈率购买某只股票，认为其价值实际上是60倍的市盈率。我认识很多属于这一类的人，我称他们为“令人作呕”的投资者，因为我在购买那些看起来非常糟糕的股票时，不得不忽略其最近的业绩记录或我个人对业务的感受。他们必须忽略的是估值。因此，他们可能会认为40倍的市盈率听起来很疯狂。在我的世界里，这可能是非常低迷的收益，但在他们的世界里，这是复利。这是他们评估公司的一种方式。虽然40倍的市盈率看起来很贵，但他们认为这将会复利增长，最终证明这是一个便宜的倍数。他们给出的例子通常是沃尔玛。你可以回顾沃尔玛在1975年首次公开募股（IPO）时的情况，看看如果当时以某种倍数购买，自IPO以来能获得多少市场回报。结果可能是你可以支付高达1000倍的市盈率，这在当时被认为是价值投资的极端。尽管如此，它仍然能提供与市场相当的回报，这在那个时期仍然是一个相当不错的回报。 连续谱系的另一端是我所在的深度价值股票投资者。这些公司的业务存在疑问，业务量不大。我认为市场低估了它们的价值，但我承认这些业务存在问题。你关注的是一些资产负债表上的价值，肯定不会考虑复利。所有这些因素对于我的策略来说，只需要它们能在接下来的一段时间内生存下来，然后找到那段时间。在那段时间里，它们的世界会变得稍微好一些，因为竞争对手已经退出，资本已经枯竭，它们是该领域最后的几家公司之一。随着环境的稍微改善，它们将开始表现良好。因此，当它们这样做时，你会看到公司内在价值的提升，以及价格与内在价值之间折扣的缩小。这两者共同带来了该类投资者的回报。

It's one of those funny things about investing that the very worst outcome that everybody was most nervous about actually comes to fruition. It comes to pass. Can we sell calls in this stock that will expire before the date? There should be almost no value in those positions because you know the upper limit of the bid. So we sold those calls. All expired worthless before the bid. And then the bid was ultimately blocked. They fought it through the courts and they lost. And then the day that that was announced, the stock was up again because over that period of time, United and the other companies in the sector had traded so far ahead of Aetna and Humana, which was sort of weighed down by the deal. They then had a lot of catching up to do and they've performed really well in the space afterwards. So I think that's a good example of a number of things. One of them is that if you're doing special situations, you want an undervalued security first. And then you've got to have a lot of security first. And then you've got to have a lot of security first. That's how you sort of protect your downside. And also there's some return in that. You also have to be aware of other ways of playing the transaction. So not just in the equity, you can get options, puts and calls and different ways of investing in it. And in terms of sizing the position, there's some science around it using the Kelly theory, which I know that we're going to get to at some stage. But then there are lots of reasons why you probably want to undersize Kelly, but you still need to get enough of a position on because they don't come around. Good opportunities don't come around so often that you kind of afford to not sort of put enough money in. So special situations portfolio is always going to be pretty small. Half a dozen to 10 positions would be a pretty full portfolio. And they're traded much more regularly than systematic.

嗯，我认为你确实受到特殊情况下可获得的机会集的影响。完全有可能在任何特定的时间段内，没有任何事情可做。一个很好的例子是2016年初，我们没有进行任何并购套利或风险套利。然后奥巴马政府的财政部开始打击那些为了将总部迁至海外以逃避美国税务管辖而进行的反向并购。因此他们宣布，不再允许这样做。这一决定导致了许多为此目的进行的交易破裂。但也有另一组交易并非为此目的，但它们也导致了出价与市场交易价格之间的价差变得非常大，大约达到了30%，这些交易预计在年内完成。所以这不到九个月的时间，按年化计算大约是15亿美元。然后第二年，也是15亿美元。因此这些交易预计在年内完成。这有点像繁荣和萧条的循环。Humana曾经非常便宜，它在收购者的倍数中持续了很长时间。六年，它是倍数中最便宜的股票之一。现在它有了出价。无论出价是否通过，它仍然是一只非常便宜的股票，很可能以高利率复利增长。如果出价通过，很好，你会赚很多钱。所以这是一种前端加载的回报。于是我们建立了这个头寸。很快，冲击风险套利的冲击消失了，所有这些套利都关闭了。于是我们大幅减少了这些头寸。然后奥巴马的司法部，不是财政部，介入并表示，现在这是一个竞争问题。合并后的公司将成为第二或第三大公司。所以联合健康是最大的。还有另一项正在进行中的合并，将成为第二大公司。如果那项被阻止，Humana通过，它将成为第二大。如果它不被阻止，它通过并成为第三大。所以我们认为，不知道这笔交易是否会被阻止。现在，条款相同。发生的时间段更短。仍然是非常高的回报率。需要建立一个相当大的头寸，我们确实这样做了。随着市场对其前景越来越紧张，股价下跌。我们增加了头寸的规模。在司法部宣布他们实际上阻止了这笔交易的那一天，股价上涨了15%。这是投资中一个有趣的现象，最糟糕的结果，也是每个人最紧张的结果，实际上实现了。然后每个人都认为，现在不确定性消失了。所以股价上涨了15%。所以我们知道，直到12月才会发生任何事情。于是我们寻找其他方式来操作这只股票。我们能卖出在日期前到期的看涨期权吗？这些头寸应该几乎没有价值，因为你知道出价的上限。所以我们卖出了这些看涨期权。所有在出价前到期，毫无价值。然后出价最终被阻止。他们通过法庭斗争并失败了。然后宣布的那一天，股价再次上涨，因为在那段时间里，联合健康和该行业的其他公司在Aetna和Humana之前交易得非常远，Humana因为这笔交易而受到拖累。然后他们有很多追赶要做，并且在之后的表现非常出色。所以我认为这是一个很好的例子，说明了几个问题。其中之一是，如果你在做特殊情况，你首先想要一个被低估的证券。然后你必须有很多证券。这就是你如何保护你的下行风险。而且其中也有一些回报。你还必须意识到其他操作交易的方式。所以不仅仅是在股票中，你可以获得期权、看跌和看涨期权以及不同的投资方式。在头寸规模方面，有一些科学的方法使用凯利理论，我知道我们会在某个阶段讨论到。但有很多原因你可能想要小于凯利规模，但你仍然需要建立足够的头寸，因为好的机会并不经常出现，你不能不投入足够的资金。所以特殊情况投资组合总是会非常小。六到十个头寸将是一个相当满的投资组合。而且它们比系统性交易更频繁。

There's two very broad approaches. One is just to approach it from the value side first. If you find deeply undervalued stocks, there's some pressure on the management team to do something. The board has to sort of take some action. Do you buy back stock? Do you sell the business? Is an activist going to approach you and force you to do those things anyway? There is some pressure on them to do something. So often the catalyst is about to emerge in that space. So that's one way of doing it. The other way is to start with the transaction. So if you look at the filings, you can set up natural language searches through the filings to return of capital, buyback, special dividend. Anytime those words are, you know, merger, anytime those words are appearing, you've got the filing and is there, you know, then you need to go and see is the stock cheap? Because lots of those things occur in overvalued stocks. But you don't want to be in those ones just in case they come apart because that's how you lose a lot of money. So those are the two very broad approaches. In terms of diversification and sizing, that's a harder question. It's not, you're never going to get the quant approach where you can get equal weighted sector bets. That's not going to happen. You know, that possibility. I think that one good way of doing it though is to do that Kelly betting approach where you look at what's the expected return here? What's our downside? Where's the market pricing this? You can punch those into a Kelly formula and get a bet size. And then basically you want to scale that down because Kelly's always too aggressive. Thorpe's been very successful. So I'm more inclined to take the practical advice than the pure theory. The philosophy behind it is that we're trying to think like private equity investors or activists who would, they're looking for something that's undervalued, but it's a special category of undervaluation. And I know that I've been reading a lot recently about Dan Rasmussen, who's got a private equity approach, but he's literally trying to do private equity on the market. So he's looking for things that have got a lot of debt on the balance sheet that can pay it down. I'm at the other end of that spectrum. I'm looking at things that they might have what you call a lazy balance sheet. They've got too much cash. You don't want to be a hero sort of standing in front of a moving train, trying to stop it with just by standing there. 有两种非常广泛的方法。一种是首先从价值角度入手。如果你发现深度低估的股票，管理层会感受到一定的压力去采取行动。董事会必须采取一些措施。你会回购股票吗？你会出售业务吗？是否有激进投资者会来找你，无论如何都要迫使你采取这些行动？他们确实感受到一定的压力去采取行动。因此，催化剂往往即将在这个领域出现。这是其中一种方法。另一种方法是先从交易开始。因此，如果你查看文件，你可以通过文件设置自然语言搜索，以寻找资本回报、回购、特别股息等关键词。每当这些词出现时，你知道，合并，每当这些词出现时，你就有文件，然后你需要去看看股票是否便宜？因为许多这些事情发生在高估的股票上。但你不想仅仅因为它们可能分崩离析而持有它们，因为那是你会损失很多钱的方式。所以这是两种非常广泛的方法。 在多元化和规模方面，这是一个更难的问题。你永远不会得到那种你可以获得等权重行业赌注的量化方法。那是不可能的。你知道，那种可能性。我认为，一个好方法是通过凯利投注法来做，你看看这里的预期回报是什么？我们的下行风险是什么？市场对此的定价在哪里？你可以把这些输入凯利公式并得到投注规模。然后基本上你想缩小规模，因为凯利总是过于激进。索普非常成功。所以我更倾向于采取实际建议而不是纯理论。其背后的哲学是，我们试图像私募股权投资者或激进投资者那样思考，他们会寻找被低估的东西，但这是一种特殊的低估类别。我知道我最近读了很多关于丹·拉斯穆森的文章，他采用了私募股权的方法，但他实际上是在市场上做私募股权。所以他寻找那些资产负债表上有大量债务的公司，这些公司可以偿还债务。我在光谱的另一端。我寻找那些你可能称之为懒惰资产负债表的公司。他们有太多的现金。所以这是激进投资者可能喜欢的东西，激进投资者可以促使他们通过回购股票或解决那种懒惰资产负债表来支付资金。所以这就是这个想法。你寻找那些私募股权公司或激进投资者可能吸引的深度低估，这有望在股票中创造催化剂。我的经验是，实际出现的收购或激进行动仍然相当罕见。因为我们在长期投资组合中只持有大约30个仓位。所以我们寻找那些在这个指标上深度低估的东西。我们寻找那些产生现金流的东西。所以我们把现金流与会计收益相匹配。我们想确保这种情况定期发生。所以你可以查看应计项目，确保随着时间的推移，现金流保持会计收益。我们还寻找其他东西，比如如果你查看融资现金流，那就是基金本身如何筹集资金？他们通过出售债务筹集资金吗？他们通过出售股票筹集资金吗？他们是否有来自支付股息、回购股票或偿还债务的负融资现金流？如果你发现那些现金流更负的公司，这些公司往往表现更好。我认为有几个原因。其中一个原因是它表明他们确实有这种真正的自由现金流。他们能够用于业务之外的目的。这表明当他们回购股票时，尤其是，他们有可能被低估。管理层在做正确的事情。他们意识到被低估。他们意识到被低估。他们意识到被低估。我已经在寻找这些已经被低估的东西。所以当某物在会计基础上被低估时，现金流大致匹配这种会计低估。管理层似乎正在采取行动，回购股票或偿还债务，支付股息。我认为当你把这些东西结合起来时，你会得到非常好的表现。所以它们财务上很强。那是一个好的、坚实的长期投资组合，你注意到那里没有讨论投资资本回报率。我们不做那种事情，因为那些原因。我之前讨论过，我认为你发现有潜在均值回归的东西。我寻找有潜在正均值回归的东西。你也可以从另一面来看，以创建一个空头组合。做空的问题是，一只被低估的股票可以长期保持被低估，即使其基础业务越来越好。管理层在做正确的事情。你仍然依赖于创造低估的非理性在某个阶段自我纠正。没有保证这会发生。在空头方面，你也依赖于这一点。所以你想要一些非常被高估、基本面弱、烧钱的东西。会计收益与现金流收益不匹配。所有这些在许多公司中都存在。它们每年都在上涨很多，因为它们由一个非常有魅力的人领导。他们有那种deus ex machina。他们有办法一直保持下去。英雄通过出售股票来拯救这一天，因为人们想投资它。特斯拉可能是一个例子。那个例子。业务的基本面，资产负债表，收益，现金流看起来不太好。但这个想法非常强大。马斯克是一个能够通过许多不同方式筹集资金的不可思议的企业家。所以这种业务的风险在于那个有魅力的人筹集了一大笔钱并把你挤出位置。作为空头，你可以保护自己的一种方法是查看价格走势。一家公司，这不是价值投资者通常喜欢做的事情，但作为空头，你必须准备做一点不同的事情。所以如果你要在量化意义上做，你必须找到那些势头已经崩溃的东西。你不想成为那种站在移动的火车前试图通过站在那里来阻止它的英雄。你想要找到那个正在上山的东西，它已经放缓并开始向后滚动。那就是你想做的。
